choices.text: a, b, c are true
a, b, c, d are true

questions.text:
True about spinal tuberculosis is/are:

 

  1. Middle path regimen is used in management
  2. Commonly spread by hematogenous route from lung
  3. Acute onset early paraplegia has good prognosis
  4. Lower thoracic vertebra is most commonly involved
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a, b, c, d are true.

 

Option C:

 

POTT’S SPINE

 

  • The tubercular spread to spine usually takes place from lungs > lymph nodes that is usually secondary.
  • The route of spread is mostly hematogenous (through artery and Bateson's plexus).
  • The initial focus of infection usually begins in the cancellous bone of vertebral body near the disc (paradiscal type) according to blood supply of somites – as lower part of upper vertebra and upper part of lower vertebra develop from same mesodermal somites and thus have same blood supply thus spread is paradiscal.
  • Regional distribution:
    • Cervical: 12%
    • Cervicodorsal junction: 0.5%
    • Dorsal: 42%
    • Dorsolumbar junction: 12%
    • Lumbar: 26%
    • Lumbosacral: 3%
  • Treatment of Pott’s spine:
  • Middle path regimen is used in India.
  • Patient is treated by antitubercular therapy (ATT), spinal brace and rest.
  • Patient is followed on with complete neural examination and if progress is good then continued on non-operative management but if indications of surgery exist then he needs to be operated.
  • Stage-wise treatment of Pott’s spine:
    • Stage 1: ATT + rest + monthly Neural Examination
    • Stage 2: ATT + rest + weekly Neural Examination
    • Stage 3: ATT + rest + daily Neural Examination
    • Stage 4: ATT + Decompression and bone grafting

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The tuberculosis of the spine is most spread by hematogenous route from the lungs.
  • Lower thoracic vertebra is the most involved area.
  • Acute onset early paraplegia has good prognosis with the non-operative treatment.
  • Middle path regimen is used in the management i.e., ATT, spinal brace, and rest.

Ans. A) Spine

 

Option A:

 

  • The spine is the most common site of skeletal tuberculosis, accounting for 50% of cases followed by hip (15%) and knee (10%).
  • Spina ventosa is tuberculosis of short bones of hand.
  • Tuberculosis of shoulder is dry (no effusion) – caries sicca (dry).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Knee. Tuberculosis of knee is seen in 10% cases.

 

Option C. Hip. This is the second most commonly affected area (15%) after the spine.

 

Option D. Shoulder. Tuberculosis of shoulder joint is uncommonly seen, usually in 0.9-1.7% cases.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common site of skeletal TB is the spine.

choices.text: a and d are true
b, c, e are true
a, b, c, d, e are true
a, c, d, e are true

questions.text:
Choose the true statements about Pott’s spine:

 

  1. Thoracic vertebrae T6-T8 is most commonly affected site
  2. Paradiscal is commonest variety
  3. Muscular rigidity and stiffness is common
  4. Posterior part of vertebrae is more affected than anterior part
  5. Back pain is the commonest presenting symptom
questions.solution:
Ans. B) b, c, e are true

 

Option B:

 

POTT’S SPINE

 

  • Any level of the spine may be involved, the lower thoracic region being the most common followed by lumbar, upper dorsal, cervical and sacral region.
  • Dorsolumbar region of T9-T12 vertebrae is the most commonly involved segment.
  • Regional distribution:
    • Cervical: 12%
    • Cervicodorsal junction: 0.5%
    • Dorsal: 42%
    • Dorsolumbar junction: 12%
    • Lumbar: 26%
    • Lumbosacral: 3%
  • The most common type is infection in paradiscal region and least common is in the posterior area.
  • The initial focus of infection usually begins in the cancellous bone of vertebral body near the disc (paradiscal type).
  • Back pain, usually minimal, is the most common symptom (1st symptom).
  • Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding.
  • The spine is held rigid. When picking an object up from floor, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine is in extension, (Coin test).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The lower thoracic vertebrae i.e., T9-T12 are most commonly involved. 
  • Paradiscal type is the commonest variety.
  • Symptoms of muscle rigidity and stiffness are commonly present.
  • The paradiscal area of the vertebrae is more affected than the posterior and anterior areas.
  • Minimal back pain is usually the first presenting symptom.

questions.text: What causes both destruction of bone and reduction of joint space
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tuberculosis

 

Option A:

 

TB in spine involves:

 

  • Destruction of 2 Vertebrae (Bone) + Disc (Cartilage)
  • Paradiscal involvement
  • Anterior to spinal cord

 

Note: Involvement of posterior elements and single vertebra is relatively rare in TB.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Metastasis. Spinal metastasis has a defining feature of sparing of the intervertebral disc space.

 

Option C. Multiple myeloma. This involves spinal cord compression due to vertebral body collapse and extradural extension of the tumor.

 

Option D. Lymphoma. This commonly involves the vertebral body or the epidural compartment.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tuberculosis of the spine destructs both the vertebral body as well as the intervertebral disc.

questions.text: The most common sequelae of tuberculous spondylitis in an adolescent is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bony ankylosis

 

Option B:

 

  • The usual outcome of healed tuberculosis in spine is the bony ankylosis and in peripheral joints like Hip and Knee, fibrous ankylosis is seen.
  • Possible complications of tuberculous spondylitis in an adolescent are spinal deformities, such as growth plate destruction, kyphosis, and spinal column destruction, followed by neurological complications.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fibrous ankylosis. This is usually seen after the healed tuberculosis of the hip and knee.

 

Option C. Pathological dislocation. This can also be seen in healed tuberculosis of the hip in children.

 

Option D. Chronic osteomyelitis. This may arise from the septic arthritis in children.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common sequelae of the tuberculous spondylitis in an adolescent is bony ankylosis.

Ans. D) TB of hip

 

Option D:

 

  • Wandering acetabulum is seen in tuberculosis of hip, stage 4 when destroyed head dislocates from the acetabulum.
  • Tubercular synovitis staging:

 

 

 

Wandering acetabulum (actually wandering femur head)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fracture of acetabulum.  On radiographs, fracture of the anterior and posterior columns is characterized by disruption of the iliopectineal line and ilioischial line, respectively.

 

Option B. Hip dislocation. On an AP view of the x-ray, a posterior dislocation shows a smaller femoral head in the acetabulum. In an anterior dislocation, the femoral head appears larger than the unaffected hip.

 

 

Anterior hip dislocation

 

 

Posterior hip dislocation

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Wandering acetabulum is seen in the stage 4 of the tuberculosis of the hip as the subluxation or dislocation of the femoral head.

choices.text: Stretching of spinal cord in gibbus deformity

questions.text: In tuberculosis of spine, which one of the following is not a cause for Paraplegia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spinal artery compression

 

Option B:

 

  • Early onset paresis is due to inflammatory edema, granulation tissue, an abscess, caseous material. It has good prognosis.
  • Late onset paresis is due to increasing deformity or reactivation of disease, or bony sequestrum, stenosis of the vertebral canal, fibrosis or vascular insufficiency and has poor prognosis.
  • While spinal artery compression can certainly occur in tuberculosis of the spine (which is rarest), it might not be the primary cause of paraplegia in all cases, especially in the early stages of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stretching of spinal cord in gibbus deformity: This is a common cause of paraplegia in tuberculosis of the spine. The kyphotic deformity can lead to direct compression or stretching of the spinal cord.  

 

Option C. Compression by Granulation Tissue: Tuberculosis can lead to the formation of granulation tissue, which can compress the spinal cord.  

 

Option D. Edema of Spinal Cord: Inflammation and infection can cause edema (swelling) of the spinal cord, leading to compression and neurological symptoms. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Paraplegia in spinal tuberculosis can be caused due to stretching of the spinal cord from the gibbus deformity/from compression by the granulation tissue/from edema of the spinal cord.
  • Spinal artery compression is the rarest cause of paraplegia due to tuberculosis of the spine. But when it is the cause, it has the poor prognosis. 
  • Spinal artery compression can cause dizziness, vertigo, ataxia, dysarthria, and dysphagia to progressive or acute paralysis, hemisensory loss, and cervical myelopathy.

questions.text: The most common type of spinal tuberculosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Paradiscal

 

Option D:

 

  • The initial focus of tubercular infection usually begins in the cancellous bone of vertebral body near the disc (in most common paradiscal type).
  • The most common type is infection in paradiscal region and least common is in the posterior area.
  • Paradiscal type (most common) > central type (central part of vertebral body) > anterior type (anterior surface of vertebral body) > appendiceal type (involving pedicle, lamina, and less commonly transverse process, 2nd least common is spinous process and rarest variety is synovitis of facet joints).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anterior. This is the 3rd common type of spinal tuberculosis.

 

Option B. Posterior. This is the least common involvement.

 

Option C. Central. This is the 2nd most common involvement after paradiscal type.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The order of involvement of area of the vertebra in spinal tuberculosis is:

     Paradiscal > Central > Anterior > Posterior

choices.text: Anterior decompression and bone grafting

questions.text: The ideal surgical treatment for Pott’s paraplegia is
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior decompression and bone grafting

 

Option B:

 

  • Surgical options for most of the cases are – Anterior decompression + bone grafting or anterolateral decompression + bone grafting – 2 procedures with similar success rates.

 

Note: Here option B is preferred because it also has bone grafting with it.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Laminectomy and decompression. Laminectomy is occasionally indicated for posterior decompression in posterior vertebral tuberculosis.

 

Option B. Anterolateral decompression. This can be considered in late onset Pott’s paraplegia but is more successful and stable with bone grafting along with it.

 

Option D. Costotranversectomy. This can be done for tissue diagnosis in thoracic spinal tuberculosis with predicted end deformity of <70. This procedure is simple and yields a good amount of tissue.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The ideal surgical option of choice for pott’s paraplegia is anterior decompression and bone grafting for spinal stability.

Ans. A) Painless, no movement

 

Option A:

 

  • Ankylosis refers to the restricted movement and stiffness of a joint caused by abnormal adhesion and inflexibility of the joint's bones.
  • The stiffness can range from mild to severe.
  • It is painless as there is no movement.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In bony ankyloses, there is no pain and no movement of the affected region.

choices.text: ALD and AD results are the same
ALD position of patient is right lateral
ALD laminectomy is always a part
ALD part of ribs is removed and spinal nerves exposed

questions.text: In case of Pott’s spine, all are true about anterolateral decompression (ALD) and anterior decompression (AD) except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ALD laminectomy is always a part

 

  • Surgical options for most of the cases are anterior decompression + bone grafting or anterolateral decompression + bone grafting and both have similar success rates.
  • Structures removed in Anterolateral decompression are part of rib, intercostal nerves, one side transverse process, one pedicle and small part of vertebral body.
  • These surgeries are carried out in right lateral position (right side down and left side up) approaching the spine from left side as the vessel handled is aorta on left side which is thick muscular vessel with more resilience to handling pressure as compared to vena cava which is friable to handle.
  • Posterior structures like lamina are never removed because disease destroys anteriorly and if surgeon destroys posteriorly, then there will be instability.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Anterolateral decompression or anterior decompression for pott’s spine involves the removal of the ribs to expose the spinal nerves. The patient position is right lateral. It does not involve laminectomy.

questions.text: Deformity of hip joint in case of tubercular synovitis of hip joint is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flexion, abduction, external rotation

 

Option A:

 

TUBERCULAR SYNOVITIS STAGING

 

 

 

Wandering acetabulum (actually wandering femur head)

 

Educational objective:

 

  • FABER at Hip is seen in synovitis/infection/anterior dislocation/iliotibial band contracture (polio).
  • FADIR at hip seen in arthritis/posterior dislocation.

questions.text: Tuberculosis with polyarthritis is called as:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Poncets disease

 

OPTION A:

 

PONCETS DISEASE

 

  • Polyarthritis that occurs during acute tuberculosis infection.

  • It is a form of sterile reactive arthritis that develops in active TB.

  • It is a rare, non-destructive, para-infective, symmetric polyarthritis.

  • No mycobacterial involvement or other known cause of polyarthritis can be found.

  • Associated with multiple small joint arthritis.

  • Chronic arthritis is not encountered in PD.

  • It is thought to occur due to a hypersensitive immune cell mediated response to the tuberculoprotein, resulting in an inflammatory reaction in the joint spaces.

  • Due to the rarity of PD despite the frequency of TB, a genetic predisposition has been suggested in the pathogenesis, with links to the HLA DR3 and HLA DR4 haplotypes.

  • Poncets arthritis is non-destructive and resolves completely following TB treatment.

  • The arthritis mainly affects the larger joints, with the knee being the most common, followed by the ankle and wrist joints.

  • The axial skeleton is not involved.

 

Explanation:

 

Option C. von Gierkes disease. Glycogen storage disease type I (GSD I), also known as Von Gierke disease, is an inherited disorder caused by deficiencies of specific enzymes in the glycogen metabolism pathway. It comprises of 2 subtypes, GSD Ia and GSD Ib. In GSD Ia, there is a deficiency of enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase, leading to hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis. Patients with GSD 1b have normal G6Pase enzyme activity but have a deficiency of the transporter enzyme, glucose-6-phosphate translocase (G6PT), manifesting as hypoglycemia and metabolic acidosis typically around 3 to 4 months of age. In suspected patients, genetic testing is the investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis. Dietary treatment prevents hypoglycemia and improves the life expectancy of patients.

 

Option D. Gordons disease. Gordon Syndrome is a rare, inherited disorder that affects movement in the joints of the upper and lower limbs, also known as distal arthrogryposis. Patients can be born with several fingers fixed in a flexed position (camptodactyly), clubfoot, and an opening in the roof of the mouth (cleft palate). Their joints are often very stiff or unable to move. Intelligence is usually normal. Gordon syndrome is caused by genetic mutations in the PIEZO2 gene and can be inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Gordon syndrome is diagnosed by clinical examination and genetic testing. Treatment is directed at the symptoms and includes surgery and physical therapy to loosen the joints.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tuberculosis with polyarthritis is called Poncets disease, a reactive arthritis that occurs during the active stage of TB.

choices.text: Collapse and destruction of vertebra
Narrowing of intervertebral disc space

questions.text: The earliest radiological sign in Pott’s disease is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Narrowing of intervertebral disc space.

 

Option C:

 

RADIOLOGICAL IMAGE FEATURES OF POTT’S SPINE

 

  • The earliest X-ray feature is loss of curvature due to paravertebral spasm.
  • The next radiological feature of spinal tuberculosis is reduction of intervertebral disc space and osteoporosis of two adjacent vertebrae sometimes with fuzziness of the endplates.
  • Paraspinal abscess appears as fusiform shadows along vertebral column.
  • X-rays can show scalloping effect or aneurysmal appearance or saw tooth appearance due to erosions by abscess or aortic pulsations.
  • MRI is one of the best radiological investigations for Pott’s Spine (showing soft tissues, cartilage and marrow changes).

 

NOTE: Remember that radiological picture always lags behind the biological process which is already more progressive.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Erosion of vertebral bodies. Erosion of the end plates of the vertebral bodies appears late with the progression of the infection.

 

Option B. Collapse and destruction of vertebra. This is a very late feature seen on the radiographs.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The earliest radiological sign seen in Pott’s spine is the narrowing of the intervertebral disc space and loss of curvature of the spine due to paravertebral muscle spasm.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male HIV positive on antiretroviral therapy has pain in right hip region. Flexion, abduction and external rotation deformity of right hip is present for 2 months. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) TB Hip

 

Option B:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Avascular necrosis. This is less commonly seen in HIV patients. If present, there is flexion, adduction and internal rotation deformity (FADIR) of the hip.

 

Option C. Transient synovitis. This is seen in pediatric patients. Since, here the patient is an adult, this option can be ruled out.

 

Option D. Septic arthritis. This is also seen commonly in pediatric patients. Since, here the patient is an adult, this option can also be ruled out.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The flexion, abduction and external rotation deformity of the hip in an HIV positive adult patient is suggestive of TB of the hip.

  • Since AVN of the hip in HIV positive patients show FADIR deformity, and other two options of transient synovitis and septic arthritis are commonly seen in pediatric patients, the best answer for the given question is TB of the hip.

questions.text: Tuberculosis in bone is due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paucibacillary and hematogenous

 

Option A:

 

  • The tubercular spread to spine usually takes place from Lungs > lymph nodes that is usually secondary.

  • The route of spread is mostly hematogenous (through artery and Bateson's plexus).

  • The lesions are Paucibacillary.

  • Pulmonary Kochs is multibacillary and caused mainly by aerosol.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Multibacillary and hematogenous. Multibacillary lesions spread by hematogenous dissemination are seen in cutaneous tuberculosis.

 

Option D. Multibacillary and lymphatic. Multibacillary lesions spread by lymphatic dissemination are also seen in cutaneous tuberculosis.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tuberculosis of bone occurs due to spread from the hematogenous route from a primary site, usually lungs.

  • The lesions in bone TB are paucibacillary i.e., the skin smear appears to be negative and there is no advancement evident on biopsy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady came with chronic backache. On X-ray, she had a D12 collapse. But intervertebral disc space is maintained. All are possible except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tuberculosis

 

Option D:

 

  • Characteristic radiological feature of Potts spine is obliteration of disc space with destruction of two adjacent vertebrae.

  • This feature differentiates TB spine from other diseases causing vertebral destruction (like metastasis) in which disc space is preserved.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Multiple myeloma. This involves spinal cord compression due to vertebral body collapse and extradural extension of the tumor.

 

Option B. Osteoporosis. This involves compression fracture of the vertebral bodies.

 

Option C. Metastasis. Spinal metastasis has a defining feature of sparing of the intervertebral disc space.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • All the given conditions in the question have the intervertebral space maintained except for tuberculous lesions which involves the destruction of the vertebral body as well as the intervertebral space and disc.

questions.text: Complication of hip joint TB is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibrous ankylosis

 

  • The usual outcome of healed tuberculosis in spine is the bony ankylosis and in peripheral joints like Hip and Knee Fibrous ankylosis is seen.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Bony ankylosis. This is seen as a result of tuberculosis of the spine.

 

Educational objective:

 

The most common complication of hip joint TB is fibrous ankylosis.

questions.text: Triple deformity of knee is classically seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

 

TRIPLE DEFORMITY OF KNEE

 

  • There is posterior subluxation of tibia, external rotation of tibia over the femoral condyles, and flexion at the knee joint.
  • It is usually seen in tuberculosis of knee and rheumatoid arthritis or post-traumatic, incompletely reduced, old, neglected dislocated knee. 
  • It can also be seen in Iliotibial band contracture, poliomyelitis and hemophilic arthropathy.
  • The "triple deformity" of the knee refers to a combination of 3 distinct deformities commonly seen in advanced knee conditions such as untreated or severe tuberculosis arthritis, certain neurological disorders, and some types of joint contractures. 
  • The development of a triple deformity in the knee often involves a complex interplay of factors, typically resulting from chronic inflammation, infection, muscle imbalance, or joint degeneration. 
  • Flexion Contracture (Flexion Deformity):
    • Chronic inflammation or infection, such as from tuberculosis or rheumatoid arthritis, can lead to synovial hypertrophy, joint effusion, and fibrotic changes around the joint capsule.
    • Over time, this can cause the knee to remain in a flexed position, and adhesions form around the knee joint, restricting extension.
    • Spasticity or weakness in muscles like the quadriceps also contributes to an inability to extend the knee fully.
  • Varus or Valgus Deformity:
    • Due to asymmetric joint destruction, as seen in osteoarthritis or tuberculosis, there may be more damage on one side of the knee than the other.
    • For example, in osteoarthritis, there is often more cartilage and bone loss medially, leading to a varus deformity.
    • Conversely, lateral compartment damage leads to a valgus deformity.
    • Muscle imbalances or ligament laxity on either side of the knee can further exacerbate the angulation.
  • External Rotation Deformity:
    • Chronic inflammation or damage to the knee joint affects the alignment between the femur and tibia, leading to compensatory external rotation of the tibia.
    • Muscle weakness, especially in the medial rotators of the knee, contributes to this deformity, as stronger external rotators overpower them.
    • Ligamentous instability and misalignment further worsen the rotational malalignment, often causing an outward rotation of the tibia.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common cause of triple deformity of the knee is tuberculosis of the knee joint. 
  • Triple deformity is more common in TB of the knee than in other types of arthritis because it is a chronic infection and the bacteria slowly destroy the joint tissues, leading to the development of deformities. 
  • Another reason is that TB often affects the posterior capsule of the knee joint, which stabilize the joint. When this ligament is damaged, it can allow the knee to become unstable and deformed.
